text: Hi everyone. So uh welcome to our talk

He's a research director on the studio

working in animation and specifically
real time animation for many years. Even

in all the Metahuman Animator releases
and all the different features right
from the sort of original idea. So,
we're really pleased to be here today to

features in particular.
Uh I'll just run through a few of the
things we're going to talk about today.
So, we're going to start with uh a bit
of a kind of overview of MHA and Unreal
5.6 and some background to met human
animator. Uh I'm then going to give a
bit of a live demo of some of the new

a few sort of hints and tips about how

So to start with um a sort of background
to metahuman animator um and some of the
sort of guiding vision that we've been
thinking about as we've been building
it. So uh we've a few things we've been
trying to hit with all the different
releases and the different features we
add to it. Um we think of this as a kind
of feature set that we're you know a
number of different features but they
all combine to a greater thing. Uh and
the the overall goal here is we want to
capture a digital representation of real
performances. So, we're trying to make
it as accurate as possible, as true to
the performance your actor did, um,
rather than trying to go too far on the
artistic side. And the idea is that if
we can give you a really good reflection
of what really happened, you can then
build on that downstream to get the
artistic result you want. So, Metahuman
Animator and the results we give isn't
necessarily the end. you might want to
apply you know extra things downstream
uh or even sort of edit some hand keys
and things to hit the creative
performance but it's a real reflection
of what happened on the day. We also we
strongly believe that the sooner you can
see results and in context results this
really uh helps the creative process. So
our goal is to give you, you know, not
just that accurate performance, but give
you it as quickly as possible and in the
context that you're working. So you can
iterate, uh, you know, if you get a bad
take, not just seeing a bad take from
the actor, but you can know you've got a
bad take in the final results and you
can maybe run another take or adjust
something on uh, in the situation you're
working. So this is kind of something
Unreal Engine's doing throughout it, but
we're trying to bring this specifically
to animation and performance capture.
Uh, another thing that we've been
looking for is we don't ideally want to
dictate to you the way you capture or
the hardware you use for capture. So, we
would like to be in a in a sort of open
ecosystem where you can pick and choose
different hardware, pick and choose
different approaches to capture based on
your situation, your budget. Um, you
know, and that might be different for uh
different takes even on the same shoot.
And then finally uh is we we're trying
to make sure that you don't need to be
an expert animator to use these systems.
So you know if you've got a lot of
animation experience that'll absolutely
help you get the best out of the system.
But this should be available to anyone.
Anyone should be able to use it um and
still get great results.
I have a bit of a sort of mental model
we use for some of the ways we try to
approach this and that's shown in this
diagram. So if we start on the left,
we've got capture devices. Um, and we're
looking to support a whole range of
different capture devices. In the first
release with Metahuman Animator in 52,
we supporting iPhone stereo HMC. Um, but
you know, any stereo HMC, any of the
different iPhone models, but we've
always been looking to expand that as we
added audio-driven animations so that
you could use audio. Um but the idea is
basically any capture device that can
give media in a format that we can
ingest you should be able to use.
If we move on to the processing so this
again shouldn't care about the media
that's coming into it. We offer
different types of processing. So I
mentioned the audio driven animation
that we added. Um and all of these
output what we call the metahuman facial
description standard. So this is a
defined set of curves um that represent
the facial movements of a metahuman. Uh
this has been the same. This standard
came out with 5.2 release and we've not
changed it since. So the idea here is
we've got this kind of consistent API.
So all animation coming out of Metahuman
Animator will be in the same form, the
same standard. And that means everything
downstream, your actual Metahuman
character doesn't need to know about the
upstream way this was captured, the
upstream way this was processed. So this
is a kind of mix and match approach that
we offer. So you can swap out different
characters, you can swap out different
ways of processing the data and you can
swap out different capture devices
without that affecting your overall end
to- end approach and pipeline.
So that was a quick little bit of
background about the way we've been
thinking about MetaHuman Animator as we
build it. Um we think this 5.6 release
is probably the biggest release we've
made yet on Metahuman Animator towards
those goals. So there's quite a lot of
improvements uh to measure human
animator in UEIE 5.6, but I'm going to
cover what I kind of think of as the big
three.
So the first of these is uh some
significant improvements to our
audioddriven animation.
So uh this not only gives higher quality
now, but it also adds automatic
plausible head motion. Um this is both
translation, so sort of the movement of
the head that way and rotation. Um, and
we off also offer improved artistic
controls. So, we now let you uh choose
from a list of moods and that will
impact the way the solve works so that
you can kind of match the mood to the
performance and we can try and get a
more accurate performance just from the
audio.
Uh, the next one which I think is a
really big uh step in terms of opening
up the different capture devices is we
now allow animation from mono video. So
this means um any device that can
capture a mono video, you know, a phone,
a webcam, a GoPro, you can record that
and you can process it offline to get
great animation results rather than the
depthbased stereo approach that we had
in the existing pipelines. So this
really means sort of, you know, pretty
much any device can become a facial
capture system.
Uh to help with this what we've done is
we've also done an overhaul of capture
manager which was the way to ingest data
for processing. So we've made that
easier. We've made it faster. Uh so just
sort of helps ingesting different types
of data and getting them ready for
processing.
And then the final of the big three is
real-time animation which is what we're
going to focus on today. So this is
giving us highfidelity real-time
animation from a wide range of different
devices.

facial expressions. So uh whereas
resolution we process at quite a low

particularly if you're wellframed. So if

so we'd really say favor frame rate over
resolution. Um, I also mentioned GPU

video processing run on the GPU and this

render, you know, you can get contention
between them. So you might want to look
at setting a maximum frame rate in your
project. Um, and then looking at what

the camera to kind of balance the two.
